job_title: Wealth Management Banking Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: 1.) Merrill advisors are a wealth of knowledge 2.) Office Management Team (OMT) understand the difficulties of this role and genuinely care about your personal and professional growth 3.) This role is arguably the best place to land a solid spot on a top-producing Merrill team. 4.) In theory, you run your own business, so if you work at a small office that fully embraces banking, life CAN be very easy. 5.) Pay is not bad
cons:
This role is extremely difficult, since you are entirely dependent on Merrill FAs to provide you business. This is NOT a sales role, though it is sold as one. You are aligned to a number of Merrill teams and cannot contact their clients without their permission. Due to high banker turnover and the generally overly sale-sy style of retail banking (who this role reports to), these teams can flat-out refuse to let you met with their clients. Something that directly impacts your performance reviews, EOY comp and stress levels. 

While some FAs are supportive and engaged in banking, many are not. You also do not have a say in which FAs you are aligned to.

Micromanagement from your bankside leaders is also a massive pain in this role. It is very clear that there is no real sense of direction as to what this role should look like. 

This job is primary about opening checking accounts (5 a week) which seems easy, but is not. Your day is mostly spent servicing accounts, calling a 1-800 number, and answering for any dysfunction that arises in any of the bank's processes. 

First-year bankers are not eligible for their bonus and additional incentives. Bonus is discretionary and unpredictable. The entire program is in the red and amongst bankers there is real concern about how much longer this role will be around.

Base and comp is below similar roles at other major broker dealers (MS, JPM, etc.)

review_title: Slow and Steady If You Can Avoid Layoffs
job_title: Assistant Vice President (Assistant Vice President) Programming in Chicago, IL
pros:
TLDR: It's a huge company and your mileage may vary. You can get decent benefits for little stress and effort. This is a good place to coast.

Bank of America (often referred to as "the Bank") is a huge, world-wide company with more than 200K employees. They have and do just about everything, so you should try to filter by roles and locations to get a better sense of what's going on if you're considering a role here.

This review is specific to my time as a Python back-office developer in the FX space in Chicago.

The benefits are pretty good and they offer just about every benefit you could imagine. Insurance costs were on the higher end compared to other places I've worked. 401k match is 5% with a bonus 2% (this bonus portion vests over some years). Paternity/maternity leave is great at 4 months paid, with the option to take another 2 months unpaid. 20 days PTO with 10 sick days plus Bank holidays and you can carry some days into the next year, so fairly generous time off.

The Quartz platform can be a pro or con, depending on how you look at it. Quartz is a custom and proprietary set of Python modules and tools. Some of it is really cool and advanced. For example, the Quartz has its own object DB, job scheduler, distributed computing, and UI tools which are all home-grown by the Bank. There are some very smart and talented technologists here.

The Chicago group I worked with was pretty fun and laid back. Work wasn't very stressful at all. World-wide support teams eliminated the need for being on-call during nights and weekends.

The Bank embraces agile and cross-functional teams. There's not a lot of project managers and the team manager gets very involved in the work-flow and development cycle which is nice. Your boss usually has a very good understanding of what's going on in the trenches.

Hiring process is very quick or can be for some teams. I only had a phone screen and a few hours of in person interviewing before I got an offer.

Good amount of internal mobility options. A lot of people at the Bank have been there a long time. You may be a little limited by location as certain cities support certain functions (this was pre-covid).

Contractors get treated like employees for the most part.

Some benefits have earnings limit levels or are available below certain amounts. So if you're hourly, you likely some additional benefits compared to salaried employees. One example I remember was for getting a daycare allowance.
cons:
Pay is very average if not below market and yearly cost of living raises are around 1-1.5%. If you want a raise, you need to threaten to quit and bring in an offer letter. My first boss and boss's boss tried to get me a merit increase for months that was never approved. The day I resigned, the first thing my last boss said was "I can match any offer". Bonus is around 5-6%.

Lay-offs happen all the time, all over the Bank. Every position is funded by year. During the Trump tax cuts, the CEO told the entire company in an earnings call the Bank has never had so much money and everyone was getting an additional $1K bonus and hundreds of millions above plan would be invested in technology. A few months later, my dept cut about 40% of headcount. Contractors are first to be let go. 

Not all of Quartz is great. There are known issues and bugs. It's been around a long time and changed hands. You get the feeling there is fatigue in investing into the platform. And some things are just plain ridiculous to roll your own version of: IDE, messaging system, source control, release management. You can get good job security by mastering the Quartz environment because it is in so many applications, but that only makes you more valuable to the Bank and less marketable elsewhere over time.

You're pretty much just a number. The Bank has so many people and levels of management you really never see anyone above your boss' boss. And because the teams are agile and app-based you never really work with more than a few teams who interact with your application. You feel and are treated like a drop in the bucket. Make sure you have good rapport with your direct manager and co-workers or you can be miserable.

Also, because there's so many people and upper management have so many levels, the day-to-day working conditions really get controlled by your direct manager. For example, our boss didn't want us working from home (pre-covid) more than 2 days per month and even then he said he was being generous and going against company policy. A different team on our floor had scheduled work from home days every week for the whole team.

Office amenities were awful at the Field Building in Chicago, but the Bank has moved everyone out of that building. There wasn't very much in terms of company-sponsored lunches or parties or anything like that. Probably the least amount of money spent on extras for employees I've ever seen.

There is no training or conference budget. Any training you get from the Bank will be assigned to you.

Because the Bank hires so many people, so quickly, there are a fair amount of duds that get brought in. We had multiple contractors start without interviewing them; they were just assigned to our team when certain efforts started. I remember hearing a different manager tell his team "we are hiring one of these two today, so if you don't like them both, pick the one you don't like the least".

The many, small cross-functional teams lead to a lot confusion cause not many have a really good sense of an entire process flow. Common to get an e-mail in the morning that started with support in Asia, then went to London, then came to the US with a few hundred people cc'ed across e-mail groups cause someone asked a question around an edge case and no one knows who can really answer it.

job_title: Vice President; Senior Business Control Specialist
pros: -Good benefits: 4 months paid paternity leave, 4 weeks of vacation, tuition reimbursement ($5250 tax free and $1750 taxable for total of $7500 annually), premium healthcare options, stock options, 5% 401k match, 2% annual employer 401k contribution, Preferred Rewards Platinum benefits as employee, paid holiday and sick time, and other benefits.
cons:
- Functional silos. Any cross functionality between departments you will have to proactively engage. Different areas have different metrics/incentives, which can cause conflict if you are trying to improve processes. Ex. Sales motivated by sales metrics (leads, new referrals, new money, # of accounts opened, customer survey scores, etc.). Operations/Compliance motivated by risk mitigation, taking time to perform reviewed (adding to lead times), back and forth on documentation and procedures.
- Positions do not list salary pay range. You have to do your due diligence to research and ask people willing to share their salary. And you have to negotiate with HR during hiring process. Annual pay increases are determined based on performance rating given by management during annual review and compensation increases decided by management. Limited room for any negotiation.
- Positions that are not client facing and can be done remotely are limited. Company wants employees to work in office, even if not client facing.
- Limited funding for process improvement for workflows, resulting in manual processes and mundane work that could be automated.

review_title: Hostile Environment and Leadership and High Turnover of Employees
pros: Banking hours are great when they allow you to be staffed which is rare.
cons: Employees have no voice. Managers are micromanaged down to their own employees schedules, etc. High turnover in staff constantly leaving branches understaffed and new employees thrown in undertrained. Lack of visibility from Market Leaders, but threatening emails, and calls are never ending. Family and life outside of the bank is not important to leaders. Hostile work environment and all employees are extremely overworked and exhausted. Change is good in the workplace, but never being comfortable is not ok. Worrying about having a banker at all in your branch was constant. Often branches are left with new management and a new team leaving little experience available to customers. Those with experience are often interrupted to assist the inexperienced. Not a good experience for clients or an employees confidence. Just a messy place to work. Left feeling guilty if you or your child is sick, or gosh forbid an employee have a personal matter.

pros:
* The bar here is really low so its easy to outperform. Nobody else does anything useful.

* If you are let go from other banks for non performance you can end up here and become a MD/Director easily.

* You get talented people to do the work, then you take their projects and throw them under the bus and your MD will manage them out, because people who know what they are doing are a threat. Works well for everyone !

* The business basically collects rent in the worlds largest economy , so regardless of what state your projects are delivered in .. if they are at all ... it doesnt matter. The goal is to take as much money as possible from the annual technology budget. Whee..

* If you come from a rich London family you get promoted even if all your deliverables fail.

* You get to see what one extreme of "interesting" culture looks like !
cons: * If you are one of the people doing the work, sucks for you. Expect zero bonus. They will take your project, throw you under a bus and give you no bonus. This is of course a small price to pay for an up front seat to see how these people work. Like a precious visiting art collection .. this is REALLY special.. needs to be seen to be believed.

Management is communicative, receptive, and professional. 5-star training academy. Positive environment. Talents do not go unnoticed. Opportunity for individual and career growth.
cons: Starting pay might be low or average depending on where you come from. But once in, plenty of room for growth and decently good pay as you earn your incentives or move up. Like any workplace, there may be a coworker who doesn't like you/who won't do their share of work or a manager who micromanages but that depends on your luck. Most people I met were mature and helpful.

review_title: Great place to start your career and having job security
pros:
I came to the bank straight out of undergrad, after interning with the bank twice through their Technology Analyst Program (TAP). 
Honestly your experience highly depends upon the team you are on. 
Most managers are highly supportive of your growth and will give you opportunities if you ask for them.
The company gives lots of resources to learn new things (ie such as learning new programming languages, project management methodology, to even network with teammates across different businesses.)
Benefits are really good. 20 days of PTO plus 10 days of sick/personal days.
If this is your first job straight out of college, then I'd say it's a good first step. You can learn everything you need in 3 years, then move in. If you're someone who's looking for stability this is also a good company to be apart of then. Just expect it to get mundane very quickly.
cons:
There are teams that are highly toxic, and can cause your experience at the bank to suck. If you ever find yourself in this situation stick it out for only a year, then you are eligible to apply for a new role internally within the bank (you do have to be a full time employee to eligible for this).
The way the bank operates especially in the technology teams is very bureaucratic. Unless you can relate to the business and explain to them why the technology upgrade you're doing is necessary, they'll simply say no, and move on. As a result the technology ends up becoming so old and becomes legacy. As a result you find that some of the tech teams are forced into fire drills on a daily basis.
Bonus and Salary aren't the best. I would say for most technology positions they're either average or below average. The bank is very stingy about giving raises. They do not adjust salaries for inflation year to year. Very limited in Stock Options. 
Required to be in office Full time. Some teams allow hybrid, but absolutely no remote capabilities.

Management never seek employee input and ignore any suggestions or advice.
Management make promises and set expectations but rarely follow through and bristle when asked for updates.
Several of my colleagues have left in the last six months and are being replaced with less qualified, and less capable people due to other companies offering far superior remuneration, flexibility and work conditions.

pros:
1) Pay and benefits were decent. 
2) The bank often gave vested equity bonuses, which were substantial when the stock was doing well. 
3) Work-life balance was good in technology (horrible in finance). 
4) They pledged not to lay anyone off during the pandemic.
cons:
1) No diversity: Bank of America prides itself on being diverse and inclusive. It boasts about its donations to racial inequality and women entrepreneurs, but they should really spend that money on themselves first. I worked on 3 tech teams and 2 finance teams, and I was frequently the only woman on the team. Every woman on all of those teams has since left. Furthermore, the teams were entirely Caucasian and Asian. This is not diversity.

2) Creepy coworkers: Coming from tech, being one of a few women was not unusual. At BofA, it was a different vibe. I was constantly targeted by middle-aged men and frequently asked inappropriate questions about my dating life, my child-rearing abilities, and my menstrual cycle. Yes, you read that right. I took 2-3 days off a few times to visit a sick relative in nearby state, and a colleague asked if I was out because of my period. Despite reporting this, the same creepy questioning continued. 

3) Bad managers: While I did have 2 decent managers, the rest were comically bad. One jokingly called me his secretary and would assign admin tasks like making a holiday video for the team, then was shocked when I left for a much more technical role. The other was a micromanager with a total lack of empathy and who was unable to give clear instructions, and would yell at the top of his lungs. When I reported this to the head of the department, he claimed that it was difficult to fire someone. After 5 others reported him and eventually left, then they finally had a talk with him. He is still there.

4) Outdated technology: Systems are so old and there is lost knowledge from all the turnover. Most applications look like they were built in the 90s and haven't been updated. You can't do your job because these systems are crashing and breaking, and hours are wasted waiting for data and calculations. Do not come here for a technology career.

pros: Okay compensation and good benefits. High 401k matching. Learned and experienced a lot. Met a lot of great associates and great opportunity to be a peer mentor. Clients were nice for the most part.

They say theres room to move around within the company, assuming you would be supported. I told my manager for months that I wasn't a sales person and would love help to move to a different department. I was told he would do the best he could but alas.

job_title: Commercial Credit Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The pay at the bank is decent. Somewhat lower than other institutions but overall not horrible. The benefits such as vacation and sick time is generous.
cons:
The company uses a top down control method to the extreme. The c-suite level managers are interested in micromanaging lower level employees. This is due to every line of business I’m currently aware of not having the option of working from home. The company also punishes the employee for not having certain vaccines. Sadly, they make healthcare more expensive. Why not add additional incentives for these procedures instead of making something like our healthcare costs more expensive? Also, at my office, the bank does not help with employee parking charges. This is around $180 a month.

Sadly, once you are salary, you are typically asked to work 50 hours week. I have seen cases upwards of 70 hours for 4 months straight, working 6-7 days a week depending on the season. Although you have great vacation benefits, the bank makes it difficult to use it all due to the workload they give you. If you leave on vacation, you will typically fall behind with only slight assistance from others to catch up.

pros: Benefits are phenomenal compared to any other company I have ever worked for. 16 weeks paid maternity leave, 401k matching, 3 weeks paid vacation time, child care reimbursement. They take mental health and physical health very seriously and offer a number of programs to assist you in taking care of yourself. They also provide many resources to help you grow in your career with the company, including education reimbursement. The company took really good care of everyone employed all throughout COVID through a number of different programs to help everyone get through the tough times financially, mentally, and physically.
cons: My only complaint in my specific role is that I mostly work 6 days a week. Once a month I work 5 days. I believe that there could be better management to give everyone a better work life balance in the financial centers. nobody wants to work 40 hours over the course of 6 days when it can easily be done in 5. Also, the 3 weeks vacation time, they ask you to put in your requests a year in advance which is super annoying and they also ask that you only take one weeks worth of time off per quarter. So there are some limitations on that.

pros: I initially had nothing but good things to say about working for Bank of America and whenever I was asked about my job I was honestly proud to tell people where I worked. Especially during the pandemic. But now I have nothing good to say about the company.
cons: They put different programs in place to help make things as easy as possible for their employees during the pandemic, or so I thought up until the day I wrongfully Terrminated after being approved to participate their back up child care program. I am the caregiver and sole provider for my niece and nephew and like a lot of people I was struggling with paying for child care after their school was closed due to the pandemic. My manager at the time was very familiar with my situation and the struggles I was having and he recommended that I apply for the program. So after looking into further to make sure I met the eligibility requirements I applied and was approved. I was obviously relieved and thankful for that assistance but fast forwarding to about 8 months after the program ended I receive a call from a fraud investigator saying that I wasn't eligible to have ever participate in the program. She pretty much made it sound like I made up the existence of my niece and nephew just so that I could fraudulently collect money from them. Now since the day I was hired I've always had my niece and nephew listed as my beneficiaries in my employee benefits as well as I submitted copies of their birth certificates and immunization records to prove their existence wasn't something I made up. But even after all that they had my manager call me to inform me that I was being terminated. He couldn't give me any information or answer any questions that I had, he was pretty much just a messenger. I tried contacting HR but no one returns my calls they haven't even been in touch with me so that I could return the company laptop, monitors, cell phone/hotspot.
